questions.question: Memory is central to the operation of a modern computer system.
Each byte in memory has the same address.
The CPU fetches instructions from memory based on the program counter.
Which of the following is NOT a reason to restrict user access to physical memory?
choices: User programs can crash the operating system.
User programs can improve system performance.
User programs can erase other programs' data.

questions.question: Why are memory address spaces important for running multiple programs?
choices: They allow programs to run faster.
They enable the sharing of data between users.

questions.question: True or False: Each process in memory shares the same address space.
Which CPU registers are used to define a logical address space?
What does the base register store?
choices: The number of processes in memory
The smallest legal physical memory address

questions.question: What does the limit register specify?
choices: The number of bytes to copy

questions.question: Contiguous memory allocation requires that each process is stored in one continuous block of memory.
Where is the operating system typically stored in memory?
What causes external fragmentation?
Internal fragmentation occurs when:
choices: There is not enough memory for a process.
Memory is divided into small scattered pieces.
Allocated memory is larger than requested.

questions.question: Which of the following is a solution to external fragmentation?
True or False: Paging allows logical address spaces to be non-contiguous.
What are frames in the context of paging?
What are pages in paging?
True or False: The page table maps logical pages to physical frames.
The CPU divides every address into:
What is swapping in memory management?
choices: Replacing slow memory with fast memory
Moving processes between CPU and cache
Temporarily moving inactive processes to disk

questions.question: True or False: Paging completely eliminates both internal and external fragmentation.
